Description: Rim sherd of Chian Grand Style or Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; pale slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below, with lotus flower in added white and added red; exterior: band of short diagonal strokes between black (fired brown) bands; below, top of undetermined motif.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Ure Museum of Greek Archaeology, Reading. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd within the Chalice Style. However, the rim pattern is consistent with chalices in the Grand Style and the presence of decoration, whilst not atypical of the Chalice Style, is common within the Grand Style. For parallels, see British Museum 1886,0401.1074 and 1888,0601.502. The Ure Museum received sherds from the Egypt Exploration Society (EES) in 1926, several years after Petrie and Gardner's excavations. It was uncertain then whether the sherds came from Naukratis or Tell Dafana, a site in the eastern Nile Delta that was excavated by Petrie in 1886. Petrie wrote that he found only one sherd of Chian ware at Tell Dafana (Petrie 1888 62), which he described as a plain piece, thus the Chian sherds in the Reading collection come from Naukratis.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 303, no. 1113, pl. 153)
CVA Reading I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain, Fasc. 12, University of Reading (p. 37, pl. 23, no. 2a-b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0866) (phase 2)
